Why use the word parallel in the first place? It just conjures up a highly unlikely scenario of there being another universe with another "you" doing slightly different activities.
If there are other bubbles (Universes) that all kicked off at the Big Bang why should we imagine that "we" exist in more than one of them? Theoretically, it also suggests that there could be umpteen identical Universes. And if, making a left or right decision did create a new parallel Universe, it doesn't mean that we co-exist in two places or one place at once.
So, in my opinion, unfortunately, humans tend to believe they are "important"/"special" in terms of the Universe.
In summary, I believe there's only one state of any one Universe at any moment in time and they are totally distinct.
If we did see evidence of a clash between two bubbles it doesn't mean "parallel" Universes exist it just means that there's more than one bubble.

Everett's interpretation of quantum mechanics, namely the many world interpretation, is certainly wrong and inconsistent. In fact, contrary to the stated intentions, it does not solve the problem of the collapse of the wave function, since, after each measurement, it is necessary to collapse the wave function, otherwise the wave function evolved according to the Schrodinger equation, it would provide erroneous predictions in every subsequent measure. On the other hand, if we do not make any measurements, the predictions of the non-collapsed wave function are correct. This is one of the unsolved problems of the parallel universe interpretation, which in fact assumes the Schrodinger equation as its fundamental law, but then implicitly assumes its violation (since the collapse of the wave function is a violation of the Schrodinger equation ) without providing any rational justification. As often happens, to hide these inconsistencies, the supporters of this interpretation always remain vague as regards the so-called “branching”, that is the generation of infinite universes. This pseudo-interpretation has nothing to do with science, nor with philosophy. Prof. Marco Biagini
"Physics is science, not philosophy ."

My personal belief is similar to type 3, but Futurama kind of touched on it once.  This actually comes with the idea that every single being with the ability to make decisions having their own Universe AND Multiverse that overlap with other individuals Uni/Multiverses.  The individual Universe of a being creates an alternate version of itself whenever a decision is made, and more Universes may be created based on how many options a particular choice has.  Let's say you go to a restaurant on a date, the choices are Steak, Chicken and Lobster.  This scenario creates three different possibilities alone.  The Lobster is expensive, therefore the rest of your night involves spending less money, perhaps a Netflix night at home, this is the Universe you have actively chosen to follow, so it is the one you observe.  However, there are the other two Universes that have not been visited, but still exist.  The Steak, while also expensive, could have been bad and made you sick, thus the rest of the night for this Universe would land you in the bathroom or the hospital for the night.  While choosing the Chicken option would be cheaper and thus allowing you and your date to go out to a theater movie instead of one at home.  Also, your choices, while interacting with another Universe (Person) will have an effect on their choices and Universes as well.  This creates an infinite number of Universes that may intertwine, reconnect or separate completely in the future.  The possibilities are literally endless.

“Suppose that you were sitting down at this table. The napkins are in front of you, which napkin would you take? The one on your ‘left’? Or the one on your ‘right’? The one on your left side? Or the one on your right side? Usually you would take the one on your left side. That is ‘correct’ too. But in a larger sense on society, that is wrong. Perhaps I could even substitute ‘society’ with the ‘Universe’. The correct answer is that ‘It is determined by the one who takes his or her own napkin first.’ …Yes? If the first one takes the napkin to their right, then there’s no choice but for others to also take the ‘right’ napkin. The same goes for the left. Everyone else will take the napkin to their left, because they have no other option. This is ‘society’… Who are the ones that determine the price of land first? There must have been someone who determined the value of money, first. The size of the rails on a train track? The magnitude of electricity? Laws and Regulations? Who was the first to determine these things? Did we all do it, because this is a Republic? Or was it Arbitrary? NO! The one who took the napkin first determined all of these things! The rules of this world are determined by that same principle of ‘right or left?’! In a Society like this table, a state of equilibrium, once one makes the first move, everyone must follow! In every era, this World has been operating by this napkin principle. And the one who ‘takes the napkin first’ must be someone who is respected by all. It’s not that anyone can fulfill this role… Those that are despotic or unworthy will be scorned. And those are the ‘losers’. In the case of this table, the ‘eldest’ or the ‘Master of the party’ will take the napkin first… Because everyone ‘respects’ those individuals.”
-Funny Valentine

It may be true that "Physics is not Philosophy", but what is more emphatically true is that you cannot do Physics without first having done Philosophy (explicitly or implicitly). Also, the converse of this is not true - you can in fact do Philosophy without Physics, since Physics is simply a science that describes a phenomenon that has existed prior to Physics. This is why Philosophy is often affectionately referred to as the "Queen of the Sciences" and why you get a Ph.d when you master an Art or Science. I point this out to remind listeners that Science and Philosophy are not at odds with one another. Rather they serve both as valid means to discovering truth and either one should not be discounted.

There isnt a universe where you beat that proffesional fighter if you dpnt lice in it. As its your fault you didnt train enough or didnt land that punch. Isnt the latter two really the same thing? If the 4th dimension is time and being a four dimensional being would mean that we could travel in time within our timeline, then the 5th dimension should also give us access to alternate timelines where things happened differently. So if we think of quantum superposition as something happening the the 5th dimension while being observed by us in the 3rd, then whenever we observe a particle in superposition so that the superposition is lost and we see a single state, we actually only observe the part of what’s happening in the four dimensional cross section (our timeline) of 5 dimensional space. Kind of like how the ripples in water would be in different places and we took different 2 dimensional cross sections of the water.

I’m not sure if this made much sense, but essentially what I’m saying is that quantum superposition, which is what I assume would lead to different universes/timelines in the last theory, could be explained if imagine superposition as simple movements of particles in the 5th dimension being observed by us in the 3rd dimension in our 4th dimensional timeline. So the uncertainty principle would actually only apply in the 3rd dimension.

When understanding the idea of parallel realities we must first take into consideration the view that every creature in the universe shares the same universal consciousness.
Now we look at an example of parallel realities regarding movies.
Two people are watching the same movie but in two different rooms. Person 1 is at the beginning and person 2 is at the end. To person 1 the end of the movie hasn't happened yet, and isn't a current reality. To person 2 the beginning has already happened, and is no longer a current reality. But both of those beliefs aren't valid.
The fact that both the beginning and end of the movie are occurring simultaneously inside the same space, that is consciousness, is a clear example that parallel realities exist.
Similarly this is exactly how we can look at the concept of time. Our past is always happening, our present is always happening, and any imaginary future or alternate reality you can think of is already happening inside of our universal consciousness.

For atheists, read this.

What happened before the Big Bang is completely unknown. All this multiverse stuff are actually all just speculation, without evidence (not science at all). But anyways, my point here is that God is real. And here is my reason.

According to physicists, all energy and matter we have now, has existed in some other form before the Big Bang. And they know nothing of what was before it. Furthermore, they know nothing about how these laws, energy, forces and all that were actually created. For some reason, these physicists never question about how these things actually came into place. And if we’re being logical here, none of this could have come into place without a proper cause.

All these laws and these matter, energy, these forces and everything shouldn’t have been created. Just think about it. Let’s say absolutely no scientific laws or any form of matter or energy or anything exists at all. There is no system, just absolutely nothing. If so, then it’d be impossible for anything to come into existence. But even if it’s totally impossible, we know that we are here. Somehow, everything exists, even though it’s impossible.

Then the only plausible explanation would be that something that transcends the physical world has created this world. If we know something is definitely impossible scientifically, then the only logical thing would be to assume that it was something that transcends the physical world, that somehow created this physical world. Otherwise, we’d technically be believing that something literally impossible happened for no reason at all.

Ok, but how do we know that whatever created us is conscious, or has a mind? Think about this. We humans are conscious. And we are within this physical world. We are trapped with this physical world. Then do you think that whatever transcends this entire physical world does not also have consciousness, when we, who are within it’s creation have consciousness?

Don’t you think it’s a bit odd that we have consciousness? There is this 1 very very odd thing that’s just completely different to everything else in this world. And that’s consciousness.

Somehow, it is completely impossible for this physical universe to have formed, without us bringing in something that transcends it. And at the same time, we have this really odd, unexplainable consciousness. Just think about it properly, and put those two together.

We humans were given something absolutely incredible, that stands out from the rest of the entire world. And something that transcends the physical world created the physical world, as well as us. If that’s so, then whatever created us definitely should also have a mind or consciousness. Just think about it. We couldn’t have been created by something, if that something does not have a property of what we have. It just goes to show that there definitely must be a being with consciousness, who created us all.

Furthermore, think about how science has no explanation as to what consciousness is. They can explain matter, energy, forces etc. But the masterminds and expert scientists have never explained human consciousness. For some reason, us humans have this very unusual and amazing thing that cannot be explained. We have this thing that sticks out from this world, and it gives us awareness, the ability to think about complex and unnecessary things, it gives us a chance to recognize that we were somehow created. It lets us properly feel emotions, and use them to the full extent. The fact that we have this, and the fact that you and I are able to think about this really just points toward a God who wanted to let us, his creations, experience what he also experiences, which is consciousness.

One thing you could say to me is “oh, but how was god created”. My answer is I don’t know. But we don’t have to know. We have already established that God transcends the physical world. And we have established that there absolutely must be a god for the universe to exist. Since we know nothing of this other world, we cannot say that it is impossible for God not to have been created. Furthermore, what if God was created by something that transcends further? But regardless of the reason, we know that it is impossible for us to exist, if it weren’t the case of a transcending being.

So we have no choice but to believe so.

This took me quite a long time of thinking to figure out. Atheists, I have proven to you that a being that transcends us and this physical world must exist. I have not proven to you of a religious God.

I am religious, and I believe in the God of my religion also due to reasoning and evidence, but that will be far too much to explain.

If you did not think this made sense, or think that what I said is nonsense, you just don’t understand. It makes complete sense. Or maybe I’m just bad at explaining things.

My theory is that dark matter and energy is from another universe.
Here’s how it goes. A while ago scientists did an experiment and found something strange. Galaxies didn’t have enough matter to hold themselves together. They ran the numbers over and over and kept hunting for errors in their measurements but they found none. Eventually they realized that there was something else, something that they couldn’t observe but they knew was there, and they called it dark matter. Somehow(I’m feeling too lazy to say how, I’ll probably edit it later), dark energy was discovered. My theory goes that when the universe was young, there were star clusters but no galaxies. The galaxies came when another universe collided with ours and gave us dark matter. Once again, It’s there, just we can only interact with it because of gravity as it came from another universe that had the same gravity, but different laws of nature for everything else. Going back to the star clusters, the bigger ones were made of gas under bigger pressure and so had more momentum. When dark matter came, suddenly the stars would have a lot of rotational energy because of the increased gravity and the bigger clusters chose the directions in which they spun. As for the supermassive black holes in the center, they were formed because the stars were denser in the middle and there would always be a really high chance of a massive star becoming a black hole and suck up everything until nothing was left in the middle.

This may seem like I’m saying what everything is, but this is just a theory. A theory because there is no current way to test it so it can’t be a hypothesis.

No, they mean the universe you live in and another universe which we have no physical interaction with.  Imagine a box marked 'Everything'.  Now, imagine another box marked 'Everything' but it's a slightly different box.  Your box still has everything in it, and so does theirs, but it's two different arrangements.  That's universes in parallel.  Now, hit upon the idea where every tiny detail forms a whole new ans slightly different box for every slight variable change and you have M Theory.  The idea of a multi-multverse has no relavency because you are simply saying that there are so many pages in this book of universes that, from front to back, you have changed enough variables to become radically different.

One way to prove the validity of the Multiverse Theory is as it states, if infinite universes are created individually upon the decisions a individual makes: One person needs to decide whether they want to construct machinery that allows for universal-travel. In an infinite number of realities, they’ll decide yes. And also in an infinite number of realities they’ll decide no. For all the realities in which that person decides yes, they must have the resources to build such a device. Due to the fact that the choices we make affect our current lifestyle, in an infinite number of realities there will be versions of that person who have the resources to build such a device, while having deciding yes, and staying with that decision, with pure ambition. If this Multiverse Theory is to be a fact, then at some point in time in the future of which that person holds the goal (to build a universal-traveling machine) they’ll claim it’s ready, and different choices in design, and in thinking affect its readiness. All the device needs to do is broadcast to an infinite number of parallel universes a greeting, message, about how life is on their Earth, or however they may’ve names their planet.  So, in an infinite number of realities the device will be successful, not a single reality should fail to hold the knowledge that the Multiverse Theory is valid, unless that reality can not comprehend the language the broadcast would be presented in, or maybe that universe’s life forms  hasn’t evolved into humans yet.

The 3rd theory is the most probable, it explains quantum physics, and the law of probability that applies to it.
For instance, let's do a brain experiment called the quantum suicide:
Imagine you have a gun linked to an electron detector, scanning a single electron's state. The electron has a 50% to be in a first state, and 50% chance to be in second one. When you pull the trigger, the detector scans the electron for its state. If the electron is on the first state, the gun will fire, but if the electron is in the second state, the gun will just make a click noise.
In this context, let's say you pull the trigger 10 times in a row in the direction of a bag of potatoes (or whatever that's not you). You will hear around 50/50 click and bang , something like bang bang click bang click click click bang click bang
That happens because of the probability of the electron's state. Since you can exist in all alternate universes created by the different measurements of state of the electron, you'll follow a simple probalistic path.
Now let's change the experiment: now you aim the gun on your own head and you pull the trigger 10 times (or try to reach this amount). Well, what you'll hear will be click click click click click click click click click click which only has a normal chance of 1 out of 2^10 to happen (close to 0,1%).
This is because you can exist in only ONE alternate universe created by the measurements of the electron, while in the 1023 other alternate universes, well you're dead.
This would only happen for you, the spectators of the events, will most likely be transported to a more probability-friendly universe and see your head explode after one or two pulls, so making this experiment for real has no purpose because only the guy suiciding will see the wanted result. This WON'T work with a regular Russian roulette, where the probability is unreal because the position of the bullet in the gun is already established before, you just lack information about it.

It is possible to fabricate worlds, as in video games. When saving and loading files of video game realities, we see that the many worlds theorem may not have been "true" 30 years ago, but it is "true" today, because worlds have been CREATED in this way. For example, a world where you can try sneaking past an alien invader, die, and then load your game and try a different path, like setting a boobie trap for him, after you have learned enough about the alien's behaviors, intelligence, pathing, responses to stimuli, and so on. With many worlds TOOLS (not just theories) it is a lot easier to survive these CREATED worlds.
It may not necessarily be true that the time is rewound to an earlier point and the conditions are explored again; perhaps it might be that the elements of the worlds are mass-produced, allowing the same experiment to run again. In any event, our perceptions cannot see the difference between the two methods of achieving this effect.
Mirrors of mirrors, or videotapes of videotapes, are other ways in which we can see that mass production for many worlds, and parallel universes might be true. Perhaps very deep in the mirror, the subject of reproduction might diverge from the original subject and exhibit freedom as a result of interactions with elements of the mirror that are not present in the outside world. The biggest obstacle in mirror science and video science is physical density and lack of powers of observation; it can get very crowded with all that subject matter, and shrinking the matter smaller so it fits only makes it harder to see. I see that you didn't get into microcosms, which are another explanation similar to bubble/black hole universes in that they can't be fully observed, but that is one very major condition of mass production required to sustain all these possible "Uni"verse(s) (read: multiverses). Doesn't the many worlds interpretation defy the laws of conservation of energy? If every decision branch created both universes, then where did that energy come from to create the extra universe? And, since there have been quantum state collapses since the beginning of time, if each produced both possible conditions, wouldn't the amount of energy needed to create a new bubble universe for each quantum state collapse require energy that approaches infinite? The simplest answer is the collapse is a juncture that only produces a single outcome, not spawns an complete alternate bubble universe. It's also the one which changes energy state, neither creating nor destroying energy.

I read a short story once that proposed a different universal model. It assumed the universe was finite and contained a finite amount of stuff. It also assumed there was no infinite "smallness". This means that there would be a finite number of ways (ridiculously huge, but finite) that this "stuff" could be arranged. The "multiverse" model was that each and every one of these arrangements exists in a "freeze frame" or timeless "cell". All of these cells are arranged in a kind of honeycomb structure. Each cell being surrounded by every other cell representing every way the stuff in it could move in a single Planck Time. A person's conscious life is essentially a journey, a hopping from cell to cell in a straight line.  But every consciousness in the universe follows a different line, meaning that every individual person experiences the universe in a unique way. It may seem that every one else shares your same reality, but in actual fact, no one else does. The issue (and the paradox) was down to two individuals, they are the same physical person, but two separate consciousnesses following different time lines. But at some point, those time lines intersect meaning two very different lives meet at the same point. All the history of each up to that point was totally different, but ultimately led to the exact same universal configuration. But this is the problem, since both of them now have the same arrangement of matter/energy, they cannot have different memories, as their brains would be exactly the same at that point.

If this theory is correct and we have infinite different universes, then Harry potter would be considered as something that actually exists.


Why? Let me explain: imagine we have a "search engine" of sorts, like Google, and we search the multiverse for a universe in which the events of harry potter (or whatever the hell you want), we will certainly find infinite universes in which the events of said fictional series are ongoing. Why infinite? Because you cannot divide infinity for a particular number, dividing infinity will always give infinity.


So, why or how does goddamned harry potter exist? Well, J.K Rowling has committed a rather "lucky" action. In this universe, it is fiction, but since there are INFINITE universes, there CERTAINLY exist many in which HP is real, because if i even think up a new "fictional" story, i will subconsciously guess the events which are unfolding in a random universe over infinite ones.

A logical approach to the theory of parallel universes.
(I’ll try to keep this brief)

1a.Suppose that there are infinite parallel universes that are all variations of one another.
1b. Each universe is slightly different from the last, even the most minute differences in the placement of individual atoms etc. would qualify as a unique universe compared to any other.
1c. Due to the nature of infinity, it is within reason to then suppose that quite literally ANYTHING that is strictly physically possible has occurred or is occurring in an infinite set of universes.

2a. Suppose next that it is physically possible to travel from the confines of one universe to another.
2b. We can now assume that there are an infinite set of universes (amongst the larger infinity) that contain a version of yourself or myself that has discovered the technology to achieve such travel.
2c. Again, due to the nature of infinity, this would mean that an infinite number of yourself and myself would be traveling between universes and end up in this one, and meeting ourselves. Paradoxically, it would mean there would be an infinite number of universes where this would not happen, even though the infinite number of universes where it did happen should intersect with the others. (If I’ve lost you, don’t give up)

Because this hasn’t happened, we can draw two possible conclusions.

1. Travel between parallel universes just isn’t possible.

2. Parallel universes just don’t exist in the first place.

In either case, it doesn’t really matter, does it?

The realms of the universe

￼The abode of the gods. Photo: Falk Kienas ©
The great tragedy of existence, from a Buddhist point of view, is that it is both endless and subject to impermanence, suffering and uncertainty. These three are called the tilakhana or three signs of existence.
Existence is endless because individuals are reincarnated over and over again, experiencing suffering throughout many lives.
It is impermanent because no state, good or bad, lasts forever. Our mistaken belief that things can last is a chief cause of suffering.
It is uncertain because when we examine our experience, no knower can be defined and no enduring essence of experience can be located.
Only achieving liberation, or nirvana, can free a being from the cycle of life, death and rebirth.

The realms

Buddhism has six realms into which a soul can be reborn. From most to least pleasant, these are:

Heaven, the home of the gods (devas): this is a realm of enjoyment inhabited by blissful, long-lived beings. It is subdivided by later sources into 26 levels of increasing happiness

The realm of humanity: although humans suffer, this is considered the most fortunate state because humans have the greatest chance of enlightenment

The realm of the Titans or angry gods (asuras): these are warlike beings who are at the mercy of angry impulses

The realm of the hungry ghosts (pretas): these unhappy beings are bound to the fringes of human existence, unable to leave because of particularly strong attachments. They are unable to satisfy their craving, symbolised by their depiction with huge bellies and tiny mouths

The animal realm: this is undesirable because animals are exploited by human beings, and do not have the necessary self-awareness to achieve liberation

Hell realms: people here are horribly tortured in many creative ways, but not for ever - only until their bad karma is worked off

(Early sources listed five realms, excluding the Titans.)
The first two levels are good places to be born. The inhabitants of the next three levels all have a particular defect (hatred, greed, ignorance), and hell is obviously the worst of the lot.

Interlinked

These are not all separate realms, but are interlinked in keeping with the Buddhist philosophy that mind and reality are linked.
￼Hungry ghosts. Photo: Falk Kienas ©
Thus, although humans and animals live together in the same world, the implications of being born as a human and as an animal are very different, and they are represented as two separate realms.
And a human being can experience touches of heaven when happy, or the lower states when hateful, greedy, ignorant or in pain. Someone adept at meditation will experience progressively higher heaven realms.
These realms are depicted in a diagram known as the Bhavachakra, the Wheel of Life or Wheel of Becoming, which is explored in detail in the next section.

Meh. I think the idea of extra spacial dimensions misses the point of spacial dimensions. Three is the minimum number of dimensions needed to represent space. You could easily represent space with 4 dimensions, it's just a less efficient model. A dimension is not some mystical magical plane of existence, it's just a line of measurement.

It's like walking up to an apple orchard, counting that there are three colors of apples: red, green, and yellow, and then walking up to the owner and asking what the fourth type of apple is. There is no fourth apple, it does not exist. You could theoretically extrapolate a 4th type of apple based on the principals of the first, but thats all it is, theoretical extrapolation. The orchard does not have 4 kinds of apples, nor does it have only 1 or 2, it has 3 types of apples in reality. To treat the orchard as if it had less or more types of apples than are there is fun theory, you can think about it philosophically and experiment with it mathematically, but it is not real, it is not physics.

I'll grant you explanation #1, but #2 and #3 seem misguided. Every time we think we've found randomness in science we eventually figure out that it was actually deterministic, and the randomness was simply an illusion of perspective. I see no reason to believe that this time will be any different than all the others. I say if you roll a die and it lands on 5, there is no possibility that physics could have worked out in such that the die didn't land on 5 in that exact roll. It's possible for a die to roll 5 sometimes, but not in the instance of where a 5 was rolled. If you were to return to that exact universe state and roll it exactly the same way, the most reasonable assumption seems to be that the result of the roll would be exactly the same

It's stupid even postulating the chances of you
"re-existing" in a parallel universe. Think about it, if your parents
didn't happen to get the same job before they met and lived at the right places
etc. you obviously wouldn't exist. And the same can be said with your
grandparents and your great grandparents and so on (right back to the amoeba).
It's a zillion to one that you exist in this universe, and so, not much of a
chance of you re-existing in a parallel universe. That is if you are ABLE to do
something different in the parallel universe. That opens up the POSSIBILITY for
the parallel universe to be different to ours. (We will call our universe
"a" and the parallel universe "b".) So why would universe
"b" be the same at all, for so long in the first place? The theorists
postulate that you may also exist in another parallel universe (universe
"b"). That means everything would have been the same in universe
"b" at least until you exist otherwise you wouldn't. At least it
would have to be exactly the same when it comes to your causality (right back
to the amoeba and beyond). Then (out-of-the-blue) you do something different in
universe "b". LOL After that, the butterfly effect would make
universe "b" completely different eventually (or at least a lot
different). It doesn't make any sense, if it's possible for one different thing
to happen it forces more things to happen, proving that it's possible for many
different things to happen in universe "b". So it's not logical that
it would be the same for so long and then suddenly 13 billion years later, you
make a different decision and do something different. If something different
can happen (like you making a different decision) then what's stopping any
differences in universe "b" for over 13 billion years? And, if
stuff did happen differently in the distant past in universe "b" (and
it should be possible) then how different would universe "b" be by now?
You wouldn't exist, I don't think, and nor would any humans probably.

Currently, in science:

(i) Nobody has defined what a "universe" is.
(ii) Hawking and others postulated that the undefined universe mentioned in (i) has a beginning.
(iii) nobody knows how it will end.

Big Bang says it all started as a dense ball of fire which expanded and cooled. This fiery part lasted 10−43 seconds, which is really short (called The Planck Epoch).

"a brief period extending from time zero to one Planck time unit of approximately 10−43 seconds."

(We still have to imagine that some Superhuman Thing or Force decreed when Time Zero would start).

All the "things" in this undefined universe ( = approx. "all existing things") are expanding, so the insufficiently-defined universe is expanding.

The multiplicity of "things" could be governed by Laws — like F=ma or E = mc².

The Laws, are still only Theories, which do not completely or accurately describe the real state of affairs. Another Theory is expected later on, which will improve on previous Theories.

Therefore (I do submit):

The Universe is still theoretical. And, even its shape is theoretical.

(Theoretical = not yet proven to be real).

I love it when someone says there is some circumstance where the concept of infinity is applicable. This allows us to create the wildest thoughts.

Imagine that the multiverse is composed of infinite universes, where laws of physics can find other forms. But we must always remember that within an infinite, other infinities fit. This was well remembered by Cantor. Something like the set of real numbers, which is infinite, contains the set of natural numbers, which is also infinite.

In this sense, our infinite multiverse will certainly contain many universes that are very similar to ours and that meet the same laws of physics we already know so well. More than this, there is nothing to prevent infinite universes similar to ours in this infinite multiverse (note that we are talking about trans-infinitical numbers)

Good. Now let's talk a little about probabilities:

If I raffle a die, the probability of getting a six will be 16.67%. If I repeat this tie twice, the probability of getting the "six" at least once will be 30.56%. For ten times this probability will already be 83.85%. Hundred times will result in 99.9999987925%. If we cast the dice endless times, the probability of getting at least a "six" will tend to be 100%. That is, it is possible to be sure that in infinite launches I will get at least once the "six". But it happens that in infinite releases the probability of occurring an event of any unit probability tends to 100%. In endless attempts, even the most unlikely things will always be a certainty.

Let's go back to the multiverse.

We already know that our multiverse contains infinite universes, and we also know that any occurrence (however improbable) is 100% likely to occur at least once in one of these universes. That is to say: It is certain that in some of these universes there is a mutant apple tree that, instead of apples, produces purple pears with yellow polka dots or even less probable things.

We can still think the following. All matter that exists is formed by a set of interconnected atoms and in this way, nothing prevents any possible structure from the chemical and physical point of view to be reproduced identically elsewhere. For example: four hydrogen atoms and one carbon atom bind to form methane. This process can be repeated to form another molecule of methane. The same thing happens with all matter formed, but when we look at a rock, we are contemplating sextile of interconnected atoms and in this situation; it is unlikely that different atoms will interconnect so often to the point of producing two atomically identical rocks. But in our case, the infinite multiverse can reproduce this process endless times and in this way, the probability of having two identical rocks in the multiverse tends to 100%. No matter how small this probability is, in infinite repetitions coincidence is a certainty.

Now we begin to understand what happens to the universe of probabilities when we reproduce a process infinitely many times. Let's look at the most controversial case:

Imagine that John Smith died run over on September 23, 1965. At this time, his body was formed by the binding of many sextilions of atoms in specific positions. In addition, each of its atoms had a definite nuclear and electron configuration, its electron spins, even every quantum of energy that formed its body possessed a state that was unique in all its life and these atomic and electronic configurations defined not only the physical form of John Smith, also defined his thoughts, memories, warts, etc. Everything in him was defined by this unique quantum state throughout his life. The repetition of this microstructural state is so rare that it hurts, but it is not null, after all, we have physical evidence that such a condition occurred at least once on September 23, 1965.

Since this probability is not zero, it is certain that in infinite repetitions of combinations of atoms it will repeat itself in the multiverse, that is, at a given moment, somewhere in the multiverse, a set of atoms will be configured in such a way that everything that which is John Smith (his body, his thoughts, memories, all in order) is perfectly reproduced, and since we know that the multiverse is infinite, we also know that this repetition of the same agglomerate of quanta is a certainty.

In other words, in another universe, atoms united to give rise to another John Smith identical in body and thought to all that he was on September 23, 1965. But since the multiverse is infinite we can be sure that probabilities may occur. It is certain that in some of these universes, John Smith will survive the run over and will continue to live until his death on January 18, 2013.

But this is not the end of John Smith. There is certainly another universe in which it will survive beyond 2013, in the same way that it survived beyond 1965. There is another universe in which thermodynamic conditions will allow for unlimited survival.

Lastly. If you believe, like myself, that everything in a human being is due to the laws of chemistry and physics. That our memories, thoughts, emotions, etc. are bites stored in the atoms that compose us, and also believes that infinite universes (multiverse) are possible such as Stephen Hawking, Brian Greene, Max Tegmark, Alan Guth, Andrei Linde , Michio Kaku, David Deutsch, Leonard Susskind, Alexander Vilenkin, Yasunori Nomura, Raj Pathria, Laura Mersini-Houghton, Neil deGrasse Tyson, Sean Carroll, etc. I have to inform you. You believe in the afterlife. After all, for all intents and purposes. A reproduction of you that has all your memories, thoughts and emotions is yourself, regardless of the universe in which you are living.

As for my belief in the multiverse? I know that there is mathematical coherence in the theories that propose such a solution, but coherence is insufficient to define what "truth" is. Truth is what can be experimentally verified and / or falsified, and this is not the case with the theory of the mutiverse. I believe in genuine random phenomena (Copenhagen interpretation) and that the laws of probabilities apply to our universe, so the day someone convinces me of the reality of the multiverses, there will be no alternative left but to believe in the afterlife. It fills me with laziness.

PS: Note that the postmortem life that is possible, if the multiverse exists, is different from the post-mortem life of the Christian religion. Dying in one universe and pursuing life in another implies nothing knowing about the life that has already ended, that is, when John Smith died in a universe in 1965 and continued living in another, he could not know that he died in one and went on another, moreover, his death did not bring him any additional enlightenment about his own universe.

Bible, Consciousness, and Parallel universes
The Hebrew Bible intimates the idea that “the tangible” universe we presently experience is the result of a higher “non tangible” universe. And the allegorical way to portray this idea, is to state that both the Heavens and the Earth (representing dimensions and matter) were created by God's word (where “God's word”, or “Breath” represents a primordial non physical universe).
But, since articulated words are the natural expression of a conscious mind, what Scripture really means to say is that our seemingly infinite universe is in fact the physical manifestation of an apparently infinite [and higher] non physical consciousness; that time, space, matter, energy, and dimensions are all the manifestation of active thoughts; In fact, that the whole Universe is no more than living thoughts.
Thus, it makes perfect sense that the Hebrew Scriptures state that, after we die [and thus leave our physical universe], we will experience a sort of “personalized heaven” (or personalized hell); an automatically built universe, created by our own consciousness. If we have had a just and merciful mind, we will experience a universe where justice and mercy will be meted to us [this will be our "heaven" or "paradise"]. But, if we were stern and evil, we will experience a universe where stern evil will be meted to us [and this will be our "Gehinnom", or "Hellfire"]. As it has been stated: “Therefore the Lord hath recompensed me according to my righteousness; according to my cleanness in his eye sight. With the merciful, thou wilt shew thyself merciful; and with the upright man, thou wilt shew thyself upright. With the pure, thou wilt shew thyself pure; and with the froward, thou wilt shew thyself unsavoury”- 2 Samuel 22:25-27

Type #1 isn't a multiverse, it's multiple observable universes, kinda. And why ever would such "bubbles" have different physical laws? There's absolutely no reason for that to occur, and reality does not tend to spend energy "just because". (Also the idea of "inside black holes" is 99% laughable and of the "oh wow wouldn't it be cool if" sort of ideas.)

It's effectively just an extension of the geocentric worldview to the next level of knowledge. Also, why assume such are "bubbles" treated like they are distinct and have a clear "cutoff"? It's perfectly possible that there are uncountable additional "results of big bangs" around us, that we simply cannot notice because they are so far away that even the light from a whole "universe" is like trying to see an earthlike planet in galaxy >10 billion ly away. I once did a calculation to attain a probable scale based on the difference in each level of scale within the observable universe, size of planetary systems compared to star clusters, galaxies, galaxy clusters and superclusters, and while the result was very vague, we still need to improve our best telescopes at least 2-3 orders of magnitude minimum to even have a chance to detect such "bubbles".

Type #2 is just lazy physicists. If a model doesn't work, just break the glass and add as many extra dimensions as needed to fix.
We can move in dimensions. For this to be real, there is a requirement for something to prevent us from sensing or moving through those additional dimensions. This again runs into the limitation that reality does not spend energy just for fun. There then needs to be a natural "default" reason for reality to end up with 3 dimensions separated out from the other 6 dimensions.

Type #3, the "every possibility is real" simply does not work at all. For it to work, it requires perfect coordination between all "universes", as otherwise there would be clustering towards the more likely possibilities while the unlikely wouldn't happen at all. It also requires that you have a constant influx of matter and energy equal to that present in the universe, every subparticle and waveform etc included, times the number of states they could theoretically be in, times the number of new positions they could potentially end up in the next moment(as in the time it takes for any particle to move enough that it is no longer where it was the previous moment). This essentially requires infinite mass and energy.

Going back to the coordination part, the really troublesome thing with this is that this means that communication of SOME kind needs to be possible between "universes", yet this in effect means the individual universes are not in fact separate entities but instead just a more complex variation on type #2, with not quite infinite number of membranes. Running into the same limitations.
And in case you didn't realise it already, who determines what "options" cause branch-offs? And how?
Either you need an intelligent universe, or you need the above, every deviation possible causes a branch-off, which becomes a ridiculously big number every second.


So, while i greatly enjoy (fan)fiction using both timetravel and multiverses, i have absolutely zero faith in their existance in reality.

The best basis for the many worlds interpretation that I've come across is the notion that the wavefunction /doesn't/ collapse, per se, but rather that one particular point of it decoheres from the rest by an interaction which renders the identity (defining attributes) of that point distinct from the identity of the rest of the wavefunction.

This meshes well with the results of a variant of the dual-slit experiment in which the spin of a particle is differentiated between the slits (which normally destroys the interference pattern at the detector screen) but then undifferentiated before it hits the screen - this restores the pattern entirely as though the differentiation hadn't happened.

The decoherence interpretation offers that the identity of the two parts of the wavefunction was differentiated, so that they stop interacting but individually continue as normal, but then they were made identical again, and because the two parts had continued to propagate normally the complete interference pattern naturally presents on the detector screen.

What I like about it is that it doesn't propose that the observable universe is multiplying, per se, but rather that the observable universe is one constantly evolving 3-dimensional section of a universal wavefunction, a section defined by coherence in identity of the constituents.

Many Worlds Interpretation is fundamentally untestable. It is mathematically equivalent to other interpretations of Quantum Mechanics, including Copenhagen Interpretation. That's what interpretation means in context of a scientific theory. If we ever find an experiment that disproves MWI, that same experiment will automatically disprove Quantum Mechanics at large. Which also means that if we accept that Quantum Mechanics is correct, then whether or not you subscribe to MWI as an explanation is purely a philosophical question having nothing to do with science. From scientific perspective, what's important is that different interpretations sometimes allow for intuitive understanding of certain features of the theory. Entanglement seems like a paradox in Copenhagen Interpretation, but it's intuitively obvious in MWI. On the other hand, Quantum Zeno effect is very hard to understand in MWI framework, but it's trivial in Copenhagen. None of that makes one more correct than the other. They just happened to be more useful as tools in different contexts. And that is the only purpose of interpretation to a scientist. The rest we leave to sci-fi writers.

Wait. Couldn't you completely rule out the third type of multiverse due to simple cause and effect? The reason our universe is the way it is, is because of cause and effect. Even decisions we make at random are caused by the way our neurons fired. So lets say that there is a point in the timeline where a man dies of a heart attack. The theory would suggest that there is an alternate timeline that branches off at that point of existence in which the man does not die of a heart attack. But, there's a reason that this happened? The elements in play up to the man dying would still be written in history the exact same way in the other universe as the one we know to be true. And if they are written the exact same way, then the exact same outcome would occur would it not? There is no variation allowed here by the very rules of this theory as the theory states that up until the point of difference, everything is the same. The only possible solution to this would be a 3rd party being superimposed into ALL realities that simply chooses to adjust things outside of space-time. Yes, this would be a God. And this wouldn't be any normal God, this would be the God of all Gods, because he is God of every reality. (Unless his superimposed reality on our infinte realities is also only a single reality of multiple realities in which every one of THOSE realities would be a different version of this God super imposed on his own set of infinite realities.

In fact that "branching" picture creates a completely wrong intuition about many worlds. Think about the double slit experiment: you dont necesserily experience one branch or another, you might see an arbitrary interference of different paths, depending on how you look at the thing. It is also possible, although difficult to "merge those paths" (quantum eraser experiments).

A more accurate analogy of many worlds, using the same Schroedingers cat thought experiment, is like this: first the cat and you are two disconnected parts of the universe. The cat is both alive and dead, and you cannot possibly rule out either. When you look, there are still two disconnected parts of the universe: one contains the dead cat and you certain of its death, the other contains the living cat and you certain of its survival. You and the cat are now what quantum physics call "entangled".

Einsteins theory (which I agree with) is that there is only 1 other universe or a parallel universe. First, consider what everything we know is made of... atoms. So what are atoms made of? Protons and Electrons. So we know protons have a positive charge and electrons have a negative charge. So when our universe was created, what made these things positively and negatively charged? Well let's consider Newton's third law. For every action there is an equal and opposite reaction. So essentially, this means that in this "parallel universe" we have atoms that are similar, being made up of protons and electrons. Except now the protons have a negative charge and electrons positive. It's sort of like math. What you do with one side you must do with the other except in this case, opposite. Hope this made sense. Here us a my multiverse theory, which expands upon some of the ideas of the previous ones:

Our universe has a beginning and an end to life as we know it. When this universe dies and life is no longer sustainable, then the universe is complete and no more universes will spawn from that particular branch. Once that has happened, we can count how many different universe there are because there is a finite amount of changes that can happen, however absurdly large the number is. Once all of the universes have been counted, we group them all together as parallel universes, which is-for simplicities sake-a set of universes.

How do we define a set of universes? Well, we can define them by using the laws of physics apparent in each one. If Universe A uses ours but has a different history than us, along with B, C, F, and Q, then it's a parallel one. However if universe G, Z, X, and E don't operate by our laws of physics then they are part of a separate set of parallels. We just need to repeat the process until we've counted all of the 3 dimensional sets, thus coming up with the finite amount of 3 dimensional universes. Of course, there will always be more as we'll never be able to perceive any sets that would exists on higher levels, like 4th and 5th dimensional sets of parallels.

"Because the light has not had time to reach us yet"

In the very first part, he positions an alien near the edge of our observable universe and says that we can't see some of the stuff that the alien can see.  And in this he is correct.  Yet he is not quite precise in saying (at about the 50 second mark) it's "because the light has not had time to reach us yet".  That light will NEVER reach us no matter how much time passes -- because the space between us is growing such that the light would need to move faster than the speed of light to traverse the distance (which will still be growing as the light photon moves toward us).

Dr. Krauss makes a point to mention that in some time in the future, scientists will look out with their telescopes and only see our galaxy.  Or whatever has glommed onto our galaxy at that point.  Local 'galaxy' gravitation is enough to counteract the effect of the expansion effect.  But the point is, those little galaxies out there which look like stars are moving away from us at the exact same rate.  In fact, they're moving away from everything at the same rate.  No point is special out there.  All the 'galaxies' are moving away from each other.  And as a result, there will be a dark age that will never go away -- because cosmology at that point will never be able to prove that other galaxies (other than our own) fell off the horizon.  Unless they read (and believe) our books, of course.  ;)

3. Trunks' alternate timelines are exactly that -- alternate timelines.

If we accept infinite realities to be true, we must also accept that there are finite realities one individual can exist within. All of the same conditions - choices throughout history - have to be met for you to exist at all. So of all possible realities, you yourself can only exist in so many worlds. There are also deeper ramifications - that much of your life is predetermined. As the ancient saying goes, "You cannot change the winds, but you can adjust your sails." So in most of your realities there are predetermined events, because the same is true for everyone else in your timelines. However, in each reality, you respond a little differently to the winds of change. As Rick said, for most of Jerry's timelines, he's a loser, but in at least one reality he's a movie star. Finally, there's an idea that upon dying in this timeline you don't go to heaven or nothingness or whatever, but you continue in the next life, the next timeline. Because you cannot be aware of anything before or after your life. In effect, you are immortal, because you are part of a story the multiverse is telling and retelling. "In stranger eons, even death may die." Gives new meaning to the phrase "they live on in our memories." Because yeah, they exist now in another timeline, actually living out the days you remember. In some other timeline, you are not here, and the deceased are. So what does this mean? That nothing you do matters? No - it's the same as ordinary life. If you fail to thrive, others will take your place. If you thrive, others may fail. You're damned if you do and you're damned if you don't. Perhaps there is a resonance along timelines - the better you do in this timeline, the better you do across all. Speculation, of course. But if nothing truly mattered, what would be the point of having infinite versions? Are we just another simulation on God's computer? Are we merely his favorite game to play over and over again?

Perhaps another beer shall reveal the truth.

A slightly different take on the many worlds theory, since people may judge by the diagram and noone explains this, I will attempt to.
Basically, in this take on it, for every decision that every sentient creature makes, our universe goes a certain way based off it, and for every other possible decision, alternate universes go different ways based off the outcome of those, where in them the creature (currently, in basically all cases, humans) chose said action. This also means that the next decision made may differ, and in the universes where the situation is the same and requires the decisions to be made at different times, there are different decisions to be made in each one. For example, in one, you could see a bus speeding towards an old woman on the road, but you could easily help her cross. in one universe, say ours for this example, you run out and help her. but, in another, the woman doesn't exist. in another, you let her die.

This is the confusing part for anyone who i've explained it to, so I will go as into detail as I can. Basically, there are also universes where everything to a certain point have been identical. an easy way to think of it is the seperate one only exists after a certain decision is made. What this would mean, were it proven to be true is that there are an infinite amount of possibilities, within an already infinite amount of possibilities, created on an extremely rapid scale (there are almost 8 billion humans, it would also most likely happen with certain animals that have, though we do not consider it sentience, and the fact remains there is a possibility for life to exist elsewhere)

An interesting theory/philosophy that is not mentioned in this is that perhaps the mathematics of the multiverse is explained by our own universe folding around itself. Large enough masses like a black hole cause bends and even holes in space time - perhaps what we are "detecting" or reading in our instruments is actually our own universe completely bent around itself, becoming 3D holograms overlayed in multiple instances within the universe - you could see a galaxy in the sky and also be in it at the same time without physically being there in 3D... hard to explain! Perhaps quantum states link in to this as well, giving an illusion of a "multiverse" rather than a situation where perhaps multiple points of 1 universes' spacetime can inhabit the same 3 dimensional space (the basis for allowing faster than light travel), or what us layman understand as another dimension (like what people are shown in TV shows or whatever). We are only aware of the laws of physics within the area we can see - we have no idea if these laws are slightly different in other parts of our own universe. It's a real interesting one to ponder.

There is a MWs theory that when you make a choice you ARE NOT causing the wave function to collapse and are not causing a new universe to form. What you are doing is choosing one of an infinite number of now existing universes (complete with past histories) to be in.  This version of MW explains Alain Aspect's experiment where a delayed choice changes the past (and changes which one of the slits in the double slit experiment the electron already went through).  This "infinitely many already existing worlds" version of MWs also explains "spooky action at a distance"---what really is happening is you are choosing a universe where the once correlated particle (a billion light years away) must be the complement of the particle you choose here on earth. (Like if you choose to pick a universe with the left shoe missing from the box you immediately cause a right shoe to be in the box---nothing changed, you just picked a universe that was consistent with your experimental choice)

"Not yet any experimental evidence for this kind of multiverse..."

Nonsense. Quantum Mechanics and Quantum Field Theory and their supporting evidence are collectively sufficient evidence to support the Many-Worlds Interpretation (and similar interpretations that treat all universes equally). None of the other interpretations work. To say that the other universes are somehow less "real" for any reason or in any way simply places the observer on a pedestal.

The multiverse theory is tricky, because there is is no real choice, only the illusion. Everything you choose is set in stone. Think of it like this, if you were to go back in time to make a choice, but had no knowledge of you going back, and absolutely nothing changed in the world, you would make the same choice. Unless there is some potential outlier in existence that doesn't obey the laws of space-time and can change the timeline on a whim, time is linear, but with infinite possibilities. The choice is present, but once chosen, all other possible universes cease to exist. (Just my thoughts though)

I think that the "multi-Multiverse" is true. We have the whole time-space continuum with 9 spatial dimensions. In that space there are 3-dimensional universes, each of them branched to make every possible outcome real.

So we have parallel universes - universes with different origin.
And alternate universes - universes with common origin (other branches of the same world)

We can theoretically go even further. If there is 'our' time-space, there can be infinitely many. Then we get to the conclusion that everything possible by one of the possible laws of physics combinations does exist somewhere. And even infinitely many exact copies of our time-space can be found far, far away.

I hate that argument: "the universe has to be this way, because if it wasn't, we wouldn't be here, and we are, so it is." That's the same as dropping a ball from your hand, and say that the reason it's now on the floor is because if it wasn't, it would still be in your hand, and it's not in your hand, so it has to be on the floor. Yes, we know that's a logically sound answer, but that wasn't what we were asking about. We wanted to know what gravity is.

And we get that if this was a universe where we couldn't exist, we wouldn't exist, but we want to know the mechanisms and criteria that caused the rules of the universe to come into existence in the first place. The other explanation is just a way of avoiding having to say 'hell if I know' by saying in a very roundabout way that A = A and pretending that that is not a completely redundant statement.

+MinutePhysics

1:11 Black holes... They're in our observable universe. Just because we don't yet perceive what's "Inside" a black hole doesn't mean the laws "inside" are different. It only means we don't yet understand all the laws of physics, here specific to black holes. The inference that what happens inside black holes is somehow outside the laws of our universe is specious.

1:20 Can a bubble universe refer to two non-adjacent areas of the same space-time continuum? I don't think so. That just puts it in the context of observable-or-not, the same as original "boring" (observable and unobserveable) non-multiverse concept. While we have no evidence for or against a "boring" universe where the natural laws change at some point beyond our observable universe, I'd have to say this comes across as unlikely. This would infer that somewhere outside of our observable universe but within our own space-time continuum (pick a 3-D direction and go...), it's possible that magic exists, along the lines of Terry Pratchett's Disc World fiction series (or pick your own fantasy genre), just not within our own observable universe. If natural laws exist in a particular "boring" universe, they must exist for the entire "boring" universe, observable or otherwise, or it would collapse. So again, this particular consideration for bubble universes is specious.

Hence other bubble universes must be outside our own "boring" universe's bubble.

I like that you've suggested that none of these three concepts are mutually exclusive. The one thread they hold in common -- even for black holes in our boring flat universe -- is that they all seem to hint at some fractal topology we haven't yet discovered.

+MinutePhysics A lot of people talk about how with the multiverse every possibility imaginable does indeed exist somewhere.  Like maybe there is a world where humans are instead adorable cats and that have lived our exact lives, only they are cats.  With the same historical events, with cat presidents, dictators and whatnot.  But this kind of reality isn't possible.  Cats don't have the muscle structure, like thumbs, to have an industrial revolution, or the mental capacity to create the internet, in the exact same time frame that we have.  

So its not that there are infinite possibilities, but that there are infinite starting points, with a finite, though very very stupidly large amount of possible outcomes.
  
So there probably is a world where cats dominate, but it most likely looks very different from ours.

One important thing neglected to mention is that these "parallel" universes are not parallel at all. For bubble universes, the only fundamental discernible differences are the universes is Einstein's Universal Constant-- So while yes theoretically there could exist a universe with a similar or identical constant, the "paths" of these universes would be determines by whether gravity, thus life, could exist and the choices therein. A slight change to the universal constant can not create a universe where other universes can't exist, or create a universe where the universe's lifeforms can communicate with other universes.

Parallel universe, impossible. Just like a twin will have very similar appearance, characteristic, etc. but if they live together, affecting each other, they are bound to develop different traits, however small, they will not be the same. Or two cups of latte art may appear "almost" exactly similar, but if you try to do 2 latte art in one cup, same logic of interaction will not allow "parallel" to exists (however similar it may appear to be).

Now one may argue different universe exist in different "cup", well, not really. Same logic of a beginning (and possibly end) already suggests connection.

Even 2 ants in the same colony will never, ever, walk the exact same route for their entire life. life itself (and the creation of universe) is based on such diversity to evolve and even exists, as much as wave need to travel in wave instead of straight line, 2 hemisphere brains, left-right legs, male female, etc. it's what I call "pendulum theory", for anything to advance, in order to move left, it has to move right, and vice-versa.

I don't believe in parallel universes, at least, not in the way that we think about them.  Unless they were different from the beginning, in which case they wouldn't be "parallel", because time and space would flow differently.  What you deem as "chance" doesn't really exist, expecting a slightly different outcome out of the same situation doesn't make any physical or mathematical sense, as all of the variables are going to be exactly the same going into the situation, so everything that comes out of it must remain the same.  Think about flipping a coin.  You may think that a coin flip in one Universe may not have the same outcome as the next one, which is the only difference between these two Universes.  The problem with this is everything is the same beforehand- the force going into the coin from the hand, the angle at which it leaves the hand, the speed of the rotation of the Earth and where the flipped coin is located, how it is affected by the pull of gravity, slight pressure or wind forces onto the coin, etc. would all be the same in a "parallel" universe.  Thus, the outcome will be exactly the same, to the exact atoms making contact with the table beneath the coin at the exact same time.

I wouldn't be surprised if all three models were true, along with some models that haven't even been considered.  I've certainly had some non-repeatable and subjectively observed experiences which would suggest the first and third.

Of course, the thing that we occasionally forget while pursuing scientific answers is that the vast majority of what makes human experience interesting is entirely subjective, and cannot be replicated sufficiently to rigorously test.  We can use tests to perhaps explain some of what is going on behind the scenes, but this information doesn't do anything to change the importance of the experience.  Give a teenager the data as to why they are acting aggressive or moody and be shocked at how little that changes anything.  Knowing why you're sad, on a hard scientific level, is often of less use than knowing why you're sad on the softer psychological level.

Moreover, science is completely incapable of arriving at truth.  At best, it can separate the demonstrably false from the potentially true.  It can be aimed dead on at truth...but it'll never arrive...side-effect of the scientific method.  Don't get me wrong.  I'm not down on science, but it's important to remember that science is merely one of the fascinations of being human, and a relatively new one at that.  Making music, dancing, making love, the way most of us feel about kittens, etc.  This is the stuff that makes up the majority of human experience.

Also, it is entirely possible that there exists things which cannot be observed, and that a statement can be simultaneously true AND impossible to test.  Science is a tool, and just as you don't use a hammer to drive in a screw, science has a very limited set of purposes, which don't include determining the range of what is true.

0:45 "An alien near the edge of our universe..." This is a misunderstanding of the nature of the observable universe. The 'edge' of our observable universe took place 13.7 billion years ago. Aliens 13.7 billion years into the future at the edge of our observable universe may be able to see different parts of the universe from what we can see, but then again, what they'll likely be seeing is what we currently or some time in the past look like, and thus, just like on Earth or millions of light years away, future life will always have a greater perspective than what we currently have not knowing what hasn't happened yet. Consider taking the point down a bit, as an alien just 4 light years away will have 4 light years of perspective farther than we will while being closer to the relatively close time frame of current day. The greater the distance from you, the less developed their universe is and we all remain, relatively, in the dark.

What I mean is that if I have the capacity to make x choice or y choice, then what about the other people. They by definition would also have the capability to make x choice or y choice. So, how would I chose which choice they make - which universe I choose to experience? And who chooses it? Again, the main problem I have with it is the nonexistence of free will. The third theory is pretty ridiculous. Consider this, every decision, every event that ever occurred was dictated by billions of factors, many of them undetectable. Say for instance someone decides to sit down in a chair, the chemical composition in their brain at the time when they made that decision paired with the amount of time they spent on their feet that day had an impact on that choice. Plus all factors are just the results of different events and decisions that previously occurred, which means that every choice ever made was determined by previous choices and events, with the Big Bang being the original event (or not, in case we discover that there were events that occurred before it).
Essentially what I am trying to say is that it is theoretically impossible because people don't actually have control over their decisions in the ways they think they do. We are shaped by the world around us and our own personality makeup. We do what we want, and what we want is determined by our needs, our needs are determined by the world around us, the world around us is determined by everyone's actions (including our own) plus natural events. There is no new universe created for the different outcomes of a choice because given the same factors we will make the same choice, over and over again. Though it is possible that with changed natural events in different bubbles of the universe, that there may be different outcomes.

So it's not "science" yet, but "speculation"

Also the Everrett multi-universe theory is probably NOT falsifiable. Most scientist who agree with the Multi-World interpretation take a 'non realist' position, ie only OUR universe exists, the others are only potential universes which are not realized.

So I am assuming that no one associated with minuetphysics has studied physics past or has even looked up string theory or M-THOERY, which is the theory that predicts a multiverse.  First of all, your first multiverse theory is bunk because the universe is widely accepted to be everything that was created by the big bang, whether we can see it or not. The only people that would call that a valid and accepted scientific theory are idiots and people whose closest connection to cosmology is a cousin they haven't heard from since grade school.  What you are taking about in your first theory is called the anthropic principal, which answers the question, why does the universe look the way it does? The answer is that if it didn't, we wouldn't be here to ask the question. The anthropic principal is a philosophical notion and not a mathematical model.
The third theory you talk about is also not a mathematical theory but the philosophical musings of science fiction writers on the implications of the collapsing waveform model in observational quantum mechanics.  There is no mathematical basis for the notion of branching realities from quantum decision points.  That idea comes straight from Stargate SG-1 and other contemporary sci-fi creations.
As far as the second model of the multiverse you are close but blow it big time. String theory, and it's successor, M-theory, State that there are three dimensions we can detect, and several others we cannot because they are curled up on themselves at the subatomic level.  Recent observations out of LHC and other atom smashers support this notion because of particles "disappearing and reappearing" like they were in other, unseen spacial dimensions. Secondly it is M-theory, not string theory, that introduces the idea of branes and a multiverse into the already complex notion of tiny vibrating strings of energy being the building blocks of hard-ons, baryons, and leptons that then build atoms and so on to idiots acting like they know what they are talking about.
Also, to address several of the commenter's about science disproving God, your bigger idiots than these people.  All science does is ask how does this work. Religion answers why does this work.  Two separate questions.  Some scientists hope that science will disprove God and that is their personal belief, not the goal of science as a process.  I personally believe that science tells us how God did what he did.  To you I ask this, which proves the grandeur of God better, that he snapped his fingers and caused all of this to appear out of nowhere/nothing ir that he created all the physical laws of the the universe and all of the mechanisms of nature so that, starting with a single energetic reaction (Big Bang), Humans emerge 13.7 billion years later to ask how did this all happen.  To me it seams easy to draw a picture, but harder to make on that draws itself.

Question: Is there actually a theoretical INFINITE amount of universes, or is the number just FINITE BUT INSANELY LARGE?

Before anyone says 'no', my logic is thus:

As inconceivable huge as the number of universes would be, the amount of them is finite (but growing rapidly as time goes by for every new outcome). There are only so many things that the smallest particles in existence can do, so for every different result of every different particle's action (this includes those in our brains that affect decision making) or even it's existence or non-existence compared to other realities, there is a limit.

More than one hundred billion people have lived on earth at one point or another. Even if you count every significant choice in their lives, it becomes a mind boggingly large number. But who is to say that only important choices matter? Why not every time someone decides to pick his nose a universe is created just for him? After a universe is created following a choice, countless other universes will be created that branch from this single universe, because when this person picked his nose, he could have failed to see a child crossing the road and killed him, causing a chain reaction of choices that branch out and increase in number exponentially, because once a choice affects someone, he could decide to respond in more than one way, each one creating a universe.

I'd love for someone to converse with me over this conundrum I just thought up the other day: So according to one version of the multiverse theory, any possibility for ANY universe DOES exist SOMEWHERE out in the multiverse. In some universe out there, God exists O_O Let's elaborate on this for a minute.

If God is considered "omnipresent", then, by definition, He exists EVERYWHERE. If there is a universe (which according to this version of the multiverse theory, there is) in which an OMNIPRESENT God exists, does He then proceed to exist across ALL universes due to His omnipresence? What about a universe which must exists that contains only an absence of God? Does this version of the multiverse theory directly contradict itself?

I view this suggests that a theory with an infinite domain of possibilities is guaranteed to be subjected to infinite possibilites of paradoxes. If anyone has any input, please do contribute. I'd love to hear your thoughts.
