"Physics is science, not philosophy; and in our attempts to explain the universe we observe we have to make claims that can, in principle, be tested..."

And that's why I like Physics. No need to ride on the S.S. Make-Shit-Up.

I'm glad at the very end there was a disclaimer that Physics is science and not Philosophy, though it is a bit of a misnomer. Multiverse theories are philosophical theories not scientific theories. And when I say scientific theory I mean nothing more than an adherence to a methodology of empirical inquiry as privileged. It is kind of annoying to hear these called "Scientific Theories" when they're philosophical theories and are generally the product of philosophical musing on logical or empirical theories in their own right.

People like David Lewis, Leibniz and Immanuel Kant are more responsible for these ideas (e.g. many worlds ideas, or modal possibility analysis) than the Physicists that crunch the numbers and prefer to theorize along the scientific methodology of privileged empirical inquiry.

A summation: All theorizing beyond empirical testing is Philosophical; and rather all interpretation of anything empirical is based in assumed philosophical principles, such as the idea that the empirical is to be privileged. As such, all Science is Philosophical, but not all Philosophy is scientific.

Multiverse theories allow for many possibilities including the existence of beings who have been around longer than we have. This is based purely on mathematics. 
So logically we can extrapolate what we humans have been able to accomplish with our understanding of the universe and the laws it "follows' to hundreds of thousands or even millions or even hundreds of millions of years of technological advances.

Just some examples: we have learned to "control" for our own purposes forces like the electromagnetic force; we have been able to manipulate genes and even create new forms of life (bacteria & viruses), we have been able to release and observe subatomic particles in equipment like the LHC; we have created nano organisms and virtual worlds.

Following the J curve of technological advancement, I cannot comprehend how people cannot accept the idea that, as a race in the future, we could be considered God-like in the ability to "create" new universes. Maybe our Big Bang is actually a collision in a much more advanced particle accelerator in a billion-year technologically advanced lab of the being we may refer to God. We know bubble universes have laws of physics with different numbers. Sounds like one of our science experiments in which we control the variables.

I personally think that the "Many Worlds" theory is the closest to the truth, but it does need some modification to avoid paradoxes (time travel ones). Oh, i first have to inform you that most of the tings i will now say are from other theories, and that i have just modified those to avoid "errors". So, first, ill rename the theory to "Multiple time line theory" where we live in one time line which was defined by the choices we made. Lets say that, currently, we are located in time line 0, or, source. When we build a time machine in the future (im quite sure we will), and attempt to travel back in time, we would actually "leave" time line 0, and enter time line 1. The only difference between those 2 (for now) is that we "exist" in a place we do not belong. Why did i say we moved to another time line instead of just traveling back in past? - in order to avoid paradoxes. First of all, if we built a time machine in the future, why didnt we see time travelers up to this point? Simple, because all time travelers left our time line and entered another, we will never be able to see them. Now, the good old grandfather paradox. Since we moved to another world line and are no longer in the source, our actions do not influence the events of the source. Killing our grandfather in world line 1 just means that we will not be born in that world line, but we were born and have lived in the source. Oh, i forgot to mention how the "switching" world lines works in this theory. Take two strings (which represent the time lines), tie a knot on both of them and align them (that would represent the same moment in both time lines). Now, when we "time travel" we simply adjust the other time line and "hop" over to it. Therefore, we can never travel backwards in OUR time line, we just jump over to the other one. Why did i note this, well, simply to destroy your hopes of fixing things in your past, or saving someone. You can never change your past, im sorry, all you can do is alter another time line and help your other self. You can go on and change the world, stop Hitler, but, what does it matter. You just ran away from the reality of your time line. Yes, you might feel better if you see someone you love again, but, that doesnt change the fact that you have seen them die. Time travel is just a selfish concept, a way to escape reality and find fake salvation. Stop thinking about stupid concepts and deal with the present situation. Its kind of like this. I say:

"I'm going to throw three trillion dice on the ground. If they fall exactly this way or that way, then sentient life will come into existence-- if they don't, then it won't."

I throw the dice, and then these trillions of dice fall as I stated they must.

At this point, you'd obviously conclude the dice must have been loaded (the dice were *designed* to fall as I said).

You WOULDN'T begin speculating about an infinite number of dice throwers to "even up" the odds.

The OP makes some key points. The first being that there's not actually a single piece of empirical evidence or experiment to support it.

People need to understand that the theory, itself, extends out of the "anthropic principle." Which is philosophy-- NOT testable science.

Multi-verse theorists recognize that the odds of sentient life coming into existence given a SINGLE universe is mind bogglingly low-- and so (as they presuppose), this means there must be an infinite number of universes.

Quantum Mechanics isn't deterministic, it's probabilistic. There are no classical mechanisms that provide the outcomes of quantum phenomenon. We can only know the likelihood that a given outcome will occur, but not predict it like we would a falling ball, or a die rolling. 

So the universe, on the most fundamental level, ISN'T deterministic, and is, indeed, probabilistic.

The FN is based on what we DO know about life. A slight change in the bonding affinities of certain elements, for example, could render the chemistry of life impossible, like H2O not existing. A slight change in the gravitional constant would prevent galaxies from being formed and so on.

The fine-tuning is accepted as a fact by all big physicists out there (Ellis, Greene, Guth, Hawking, Linde, Page, Rees, Susskind, Wheeler, etc.), so the FN is not under question here, but it's implications are.

Can you truly be certain that only a small set of initial conditions would support life, compared with the set of possible outcomes? It is difficult to gauge the effects of alternative conditions, since our current sample size is n=1.

Not to be disagreeable, but I think the idea behind a circle is physically motivated. It is the set of points which are the same specified "distance" from a single point. This concept of "distance" is physically motivated. In a universe with alternative laws of physics, distance might follow different rules, and the circle would look different as a result.

I've heard of Godel's incompleteness theorems, but I don't know a lot about them. However, I've never heard that they can be used to argue for the existence of god or the supernatural, etc. (Even though Godel was a staunch Christian, I think that he just had strong convictions for his beliefs.)

The fine-tuning is impossible to be explained by naturalistic processes if our universe is the only one that exists (by "our" universe I mean with the laws of physics, constants and initial conditions that we have observed). Out of all the set of possible laws/constants, only a tiny fraction are life-friendly. The immense improbability of the fine tuning makes straightforward appeals to chance untenable.

Hence, if our universe is the only one, chance was not involved in it's origin.

I was talking specifically about universes that are 100% separate from our own--that have never interacted with ours, and never will in the future. I also fail to see how the fine-tuning of physical constants enforces the necessary belief in alternative universes. Can you elaborate?

Physicists might not study the idea of other universes, however they have no choice but to believe in those other universes' existence if they're to keep within a materialistic theory of origins, or else the fine-tunning of the initial conditions, physical constants and laws of physics of our universe are impossible to explain through the filter of methodological naturalism.

First, pi is not just a constant. It represents the ratio between the diameter and circumference of a circle. In a universe where physics is slightly different, the equivalent of "circles" there may have a slightly different ratio than our known. Thus, a different value would be assigned to pi in this universe.

Second, no one is saying that a universe with no ties to our own cannot exist. However, such a universe could never, ever, ever be verified. Physicists usually do not study such things.

Another idea that I've heard of and like is the idea of the "Omniverse", which is defined thusly:

Universe = our home reality based on our current decisions
Multiverse = All possible decisions using our physical laws.
Omniverse = All possibilities using ANY physical laws (e.g. Gravity repels instead of attracts, no Weak Nuclear Force, atoms only have protons, etc).

Unfortunately it's just philosophy: the Omniverse not only probably isn't observable, but might be downright dangerous to observe.

Schrodinger's Cat is purely a thought experiment to allow people to visualize quantum mechanics. The idea: a cat and a switch are placed in a box (we cannot see inside). An electron whose spin is not known is sent into the box. If it is spin up, it will fly upward and hit the switch, which releases poison and kills the cat. If it is spin down, it will miss the switch. Now because the electron has not been measured, it is both down and up. The cat is also alive AND dead, until we check the box.

Well, I think this is one of the first times someone practically explained Schrodinger's cat to me. And as a sober thinking individual, I find it ridiculous. If something like that can change, then it's possible for anything to be different inside the box. In fact, if you put a computer in there that would calculate 2+2 a million times, without anyone being able to see... it could turn out as 5 at some point. Which it can't and won't. That theory is nothing but not knowing what's in the dark.

No problem :)

Now when you say a solar system with the same "history" as ours, this introduces a new ambiguity, because it is not entirely known if the history of the solar system is finite or not (that is, were there events prior to the big bang that need to be considered?) Two galaxies with identical infinite histories have zero probability for certain.

Finally, two identical galaxies within the same universe interact with one another regardless of distance; another complication to address.

The third theory is actually, I believe, the most likely. Like Schrodinger's Cat, there are certain quantities in physics that have a probability of being in both of two different states until they are measured. To justify this logical gap between probability and certainty, some believe that each time such a measurement is made, the universe "splits" to represent all possible outcomes: e.g. one in which the cat definitively lives, the other in which it dies.

1. All men are mortal (observation)
2. I am a man (observation)
3. I am mortal (inductive reasoning)

The Everettian interpretation doesn’t say that there exists a universe for every possibility, in how we normally think of as being “possible”, like model possibility or logical possibility. But rather says that there exists a universe for every possible quantum state, that is everything that has an above zero quantum amplitude in the wavefunction of the universe. These universes are completely causally disconnected.

"can you explain what is "nothing"? nothingness...what is it?" It turns out to be increasingly more likely that absolute nothingness does not actually exist (or ever has existed). Although there is still no established scientific theory on this subject, there are indications that space itself behaves a bit like computer memory: you can reset all information contained in it, but that will still leave you with a huge bunch of zeros in the underlying hardware, and not with 'nothing'.

"[..] so what is nothingness?" Now that is a much more shakey subject, scientifically. Because we lack a proper theory of quantumgravity, we cannot really know for sure what physical 'nothingness' actually means. There are many candidate-theories that predict that absolute nothingness does not physically exists. There is increasing evidence that even empty space itself has a non-zero energy, meaning it's never 100% completely empty. But it is so far unknown what the implications of this are.

"the big bang is just a theory...so what is nothingness?" In science, for something to be considered an accepted 'theory', it has to be a lot more then just an idea that someone made up. Theories in science are more or less established facts, supported by tons and tons of empirical evidence. The Big Bang is not 'just' a theory. It's a solid explanation that is on par with the theory of General Relativity, quantum-mechanics, evolution-theory, and the theory of plate tectonics.

The anthropic principle does not explain our existence: the weak anthropic principle (WAP) says that we know that the properties of the universe must be amenable to life like us because we exist to observe those properties.

These properties don't exist because we need them to exist, but rather we exist because of these properties.

The only alternatives to the weak anthropic principle are the Completely Ridiculous Anthropic Principles.

Side Note: You are mixing up anti-matter and dark matter. 

Anti-matter behaves exactly like normal matter, except with "opposite" properties (e.g., anti-matter electrons have positive charge). Every particle-type of matter should have an anti-matter counterpart - a "mirror image" of sorts.

Dark matter, on the other hand, is a type of matter that does not interact with the electromagnetic force, which means that it neither absorbs nor emits light.

Killing you in every universe isn't possible, because showing up to kill you would also be a branch point: all that it would do is create a universe where this person showed up and killed you. There would still be another universe where this person never showed up and therefore couldn't kill you in that universe. 

If the person tried to jump to that universe, it would create *another* branch point, and the problem repeats itself.

Not really random theories. The theories are based on our current understanding of general relativity and quantum mechanics. Both general relativity and quantum mechanics have been observed to be true. The problem is that the two, as we know it now, are incompatible with each other. The theories here are meant to resolve this problem in search for the Grand Unified Theory (GUT) and the Theory of Everything (ToE), such as String Theory, which will unify general relativity and quantum mechanics.

There is a difference between something being *probabilistic* and being completely random. 

Just because something is not "completely determined" does not mean that every conceivable outcome is one of the possible outcomes. All it means is that there are multiple possible outcomes. For example, the decision of whether to have eggs or cereal in the morning might be the result of a probabilistic process rather than a deterministic one, even though all possible outcomes fall under "breakfast."

Agnosticism is not the stance that you're not sure. It's an epistemological construct on the nature of knowledge. An agnostic thinks it's wholly unknowable whether or not a god exists. One can be an atheist and agnostic at the same time and by far most atheists are also agnostic. But an agnostic could also be a theist who recognises that his claims are uncertain. They are labels on different levels of the debate not bordering exclusive grades. :)

4:18 Gonna have to disagree with physics not being philosophy. Physics, the king of science, is indeed philosophy as is all of Science, and the scientific method. It is a small subset of philosophy concerned with the truth about the physical/natural world, and was originally called "natural philosophy" because it was and is indeed the natural philosophy. It is supposedly a set of truths that are intended to coincide with a singular universe of reality.

These ideas are in the "hypothesis" stage of the scientific model. In order to make a sound conclusion about any system, we must guess to why it behaves the way it does, then set out to prove it. We don't have the technology (yet) to truly test these theories, but we do have to start somewhere, don't we?
But yes, theoretical physicists are getting a little ahead of themselves.

The difficulty here is that π is a mathematical constant rather than a physical constant. Regardless of the properties of the physical universe it would always be true that in a hypothetical Euclidean plane the ratio of a circle's circumference to its diameter would be the same π we're all familiar with. What might change, though, would be how useful the number π is at representing another weirdly warped universe that had different physical constants.

The idea isn't that the universe is actually branching - that is just a convenient way of drawing it. The actual idea is built on Quantum Mechanics.

In Quantum Mechanics, a particle's position, momentum, etc. are aspects of something called the particle's "wave function." The problem is that a single wave function can encompass many potential positions, momenta, etc. - each a harmonic of the total wave.

The Many Worlds interpretation is based on an idea of how we interact with these harmonics.

The "expansion" of the (observable) universe occurs through a General Relativistic process. General Relativity operates on the idea that the presence of a massive object can distort the distance between two points in spacetime.

The idea of the Big Bang/expansion of the universe is that something similar is happening over time with distances in space. Consequently two objects that are not moving away from one another can still wind up getting farther apart due this expansion.

It doesn't have anything directly to do with your decisions. The basic idea of many worlds is that particles which exist in superposition have component wave functions which interfere with each other (so to speak). When a complex interaction takes place, these wave functions change to such a degree that they never interfere with each other again. Interfering components is what gives the "wave-like" qualities to particles, while becoming non-interfering makes it act more like a classical particle

Yes, it does. It's mathematically certain. For a thing that has a probability of happening that is x, after n trials the probability that the event has not occurred at all is (1-x)^n. for non-zero x (that is, the probability of the thing happening in each trial is greater than 0) this number tends to 0 as n tends to infinity.

No. Things that are logically impossible are logically impossible over all observable universes. If a certain event has a larger than 0 probability of happening, then the many-worlds multiverse theory states that it must occur somewhere. But if there are multiverses, then the chances of the multiverse theory not being true is 0. So it won't happen anywhere. Anything that CAN happen does. If you draw a card from a standard deck, there's always a 0% chance of you drawing a 16 of spades.

Basically, I'll take a simple situation (say waiting at a bus stop) and try to imagine EVERY possible outcome.  Its impossible.

Heres one:  if there are 6 seats at a bus stop and 10 people are waiting for 3 separate buses, how many different seating arrangements are there?  This doesn't even factor in time (asides from buses stopping).

When an object is falling with its terminal velocity, the gravity and air resistance are equal. Therefore the total force that accelerates the object is zero. Acceleration isn't the same as velocity so whether an object has acceleration or not doesn't reveal anything about it's velocity. 
So, gravity and air resistance affect the object but they're equal and it's acceleration is 0 which is why its velocity won't go past its terminal velocity.
